text: I came into the ER concerned about a lump on the side of my neck. I have a past history of Lymphoma which is why i  became very concerned. I checked in, waited 10 hours to have a Blood Test and X Ray done and another 3hrs to get the result. The first day experience was alright other than the wait time for a couple of simple operations. I was requested to come back the next day for a Ultra Sound. The Ultra Sound was what found my Lymphoma years ago. Knowing this I was concerned ,but knew it was the last test that would confirm my Cancer didn't come back. After having the Ultra Sound I was told to wait in the ER waiting room for my results by the Ultra Scan technician. I waited for 9hrs before I went to the front desk to check on my status. Only to find out I wasn't checked in and I would have to check in all over again. Horrified after patiently waiting I pleaded that I shouldn't have to wait another 9hrs. Thankfully the front check in lady listened to my concerns and took the time to back track the information to see that infact I had been there since 10:20am as requested by the Ultra Sound Technician. She apologized and said she would get me in as soon as she could, of course as long as it didn't impeed a more critical patient, which was understandable. The ER check in Nurse got me in right away and I sat in room waiting for the results of the Ultra Sound to be explained by a Doctor. That's when a Nurse came in the room, the same one that asked me about my symptoms at the ER check in the day before. She asked about my symptoms like I had never been there, horrified again thinking I just wasted almost 25hrs in the last two days to be no further ahead. About 30 mins later the doctor came in and told me the results were good and I should get it looked at again in the 3 months. I am not a doctor ,but when it only took about 20 minutes from the time my situation of not being a patient in the system to being told my Ultra Sound results were good seems very quick to be 100% the result of the Ultra Scan. I left feeling releived and with doubt ,but also horrified with with lack of organization to keep track of patients. I remember reading the sign that said wait times are as follows based on the sign for 9 out of 10 people. I wondered what the 10th person wait time would be, I guess the 10th person is the person that is forgotten about..I now know. The 2 stars are for the ER check in Nurse that worked on Dec2@9:00pm that apologized and actually carried through for me, Thank You. The 3 missing stars are for the suffering of having to sit there for 9hrs pondering the results of a test that would determine the outcome of my future.

I want to express a huge gratitude to all medical personnel who took care of me while I was there: surgery daycare nurses - Ella and Gwen; transportation between departments - Jesse and Bob; radiology department - dr. Maria Koleva, nurse Michael and other nurses; after procedure nurse - Hayley.
Thank you so much for your amazing care! You all making such a huge difference!

My husband went in with and infection, he waited patiently but when he went to the desk to report his changes (like the sign says to do) the "person" at the desk said it's not her job and to tell the nurses at their station. She was very rude to many people and not helpful or kind at all. The rest of the staff was wonderful. I wish we had this rude persons name so we could report her properly.

Thank you to nurses Alex, Alexa, Lauren Kyle(ER), Francis, and the trauma team. I appreciate the care you gave me.
My story:
I was brought in by ambulance 9am Friday.  I was first brought into the trauma room because my heart rate was so low.  The trauma team was AMAZING!
I stayed 5 days in the hospital.  They did a lot of tests.  I am very appreciative of that.
I, as a patient, heard a lot of things the staff was saying about my heart BUT no one communicated anything at all to me (heart failure, cardiac arrest, heart muscle death, cancer, tumor) I saw countless Drs and no one knew my medical history.  I was ignored dismissed and honestly terrified I was dying.  I asked for a shower numerous times but was told it was inconvenient.  Everything that was missed, or lost (like my signed consent form for surgery) was blamed on their “new system”
After all that on the fifth day I was literally told… there’s nothing wrong and I left the hospital feeling worse than I felt the first day. As I lay here right now my heart is tight

I recently received care at Victoria General for the first time in nearly a decade, and I am incredibly grateful for the exceptional treatment I experienced. From the moment I arrived, the entire staff showed genuine warmth, compassion, and professionalism. They consistently went above and beyond to ensure my comfort and well-being.

Their dedication and attentiveness made an extremely difficult time much more manageable. I am truly thankful for the outstanding care and kindness I received from everyone at Victoria General, from the Emergency Room staff and testing staff to those on the 4th floor. Thank you for all that you do, sincerely.
I arrived at 7:40 to take an X-ray and they saw me immediately. If you need x-rays, it's just walk-in. I was very impressed and happy to be in and out in less than 20 minutes.

They killed my partner of eight years with their incompetence.

First, the surgery was supposed to be an overnight stay in ICU. I would rather get a sewing needle and do it myself then to trust Dr. Fleetwood's competence. If only I took him to competent doctors that actually cared about their patients instead!

The ICU nurses do not care about your loved ones either. I visited every day and watched them stand around chit-chatting. Certainly not talking about the tasks at hand. One by one I watched the patients slowly pass away. Despite machines constantly going off, nurses rarely came in to check on  my partner. He pulled sensitive equipment out in an attempt to help himself in his confused state. He quickly went downhill, but nothing was really done to help. CT scans done over and over again with no real other steps taken to address his worsening condition.

He was only in his early forties and I'm now a widow in my late thirties. Honestly wish I never encouraged the surgery. He would have lived longer simply allowing nature to take its course. It's sickening Canadians even have to pay into this medical system. At least in the States you die because you can't afford treatment. In Canada, we die while getting taxed for inadequate care. This hospital convinced me not to bother with getting medical treatment in the future. It's too bad I can't opt out of the waste of money and keep it for loved ones to inherit.

Edit: I forgot to include the nurse who set up the appointment also contributed to his death by ignoring him when he mentioned he recently received medication for an infection. He ended up passing away from an infection. So pretty much everyone at this hospital doesn't care at all or do the barest minimum to improve survival. Again, you are better off letting nature take it's course as you will live longer.

The child life specialists at VGH are absolute miracle workers and have made such an amazing difference in the life of my highly anxious child when receiving/needing medical care. We are so thankful for them! Make sure to ask for them if you have a child who needs extra support.
All the other experiences with staff we've had at vgh for either myself or my child in other departments have all also been positive.

We don't have many choices for hospitals and the people that work here generally are kind and good people but our healthcare system is being taken out at the knees and as a result all our hospitals are understaffed and overworked.
I pray that nobody in this world models their healthcare system after Canada's because it will be doomed to fail right out of the gate.
These people are doing the best work that they can with what they've got so just try to remember to be kind and cut them some slack and be prepared for long wait times.
I had multiple pneumothoresis and had tremendous difficulty breathing with a 70% collapse and I still was in the waiting room for 4 hours before they saw me, that's insane.

Worst hospital I have ever been to . The doctors I dealt with were super rude . I went in because I have been having bad vertigo and super dizzy . Had sharp pain in my chest and troubles breathing . After running some tests they couldn’t figure it out . They refused to send me to a ent specialist and my symptoms are only getting worse. They told me not to come back and go to the urgent care .

My wife and I were in the emergency room on June 16th for over 8 hours from 2:30pm-10:30pm waiting to see a doctor for my wife's rib that was out of place and causing severe pain with a resting heart rate of 140.  When we were the next ones to see the doctor, some other patient came in with a gun shot wound and the doctors immediately rushed to see him. A few minutes later the police arrived and told everyone to leave as the hospital is going into lock down. I attempted speaking to staff and they ignored me and said leave immediately. I then helped not only my wife, but also some other patient who was a pregnant woman with a concussion back to my car and drove them both home.

I called the next morning asking if we were able to schedule something to see a doctor and explained the situation of how we waited the day prior and were told to leave by the police. They said there is nothing they can do for us and we have to just start the whole process again.

Unless you are unconscious and paramedics have to take you to this hospital, don't go to the ER. After making my severely injured wife wait for over 8 hours, they had no compassion to send us away and make us do the whole thing again the following day.

Oh, almost forgot to mention they had to take my wife's blood sample twice because they somehow lost the first one. I'm sure this is a very professionally run hospital with great staff, but this experience made me never want to put my wife or myself through that again.

I had 2 visits in the last month and half. My only beef was the wait. First one was 6+
The second time was 12. VGH and RJH needs more DR'S!  Come on gvt. Give more funding!
No excuse!!  Staff are doing their best- Kudos to them. Much appreciated!

If possible I could have given a minus star to the hospital and the staff. I got bitten by something while on work and after the initial diagnosis my manager recommended me to visit emergency. I went to Victoria General Hospital and …

More than 2 days  waiting just know about the medical imaging report of pregnant women. My wife suffering from pain and bleeding during early pregnancy but still much more longer waiting of dr. That is un-terrible

Been waiting over 5 hours in emergency with severe stomach pain while they've been letting in people for broken fingers and toes who got here hours after me. Worst emergency room experience of my life, next time I'm driving up to Duncan or Nanaimo. Embarassing.

It's a hospital.   We had an appt.  Not everything in this hospital needs an appt.  As there are emergency services...so you walk right in for that.  The entrance for ED is on the opposite side of the main entrance.  You can pay for parking via the public parking app.  Or you can pay at a machine, but you have to walk a distance to pay.

I cannot thank the incredible team of nurses, doctors and medical students enough for their unwavering dedication and compassion in taking care of my 3 month old son. He was in their capable hands, and they went above and beyond to ensure his well-being.  The staff at this hospital have always treated us kindly and we leave with all questions answered and all problems solved. I haven't had a bad experience here once and can rest easy knowing we have so amazing medical personnel just down the road when we need it.  Thank you for all that you do!

The triage staff in the Emergency area informed us that babies do not have priority over adults. They should instead go “with the regular flow”. We have a stretched-thin health care system and crappy health workers too. Not all of them are “heroes without capes”.

The staff and doctor were so nice a comforting
I don't don't put wait times on the hospital staff.
How many people go there when they don't need to...
The Picu and Pediatric ward nurses and doctors are absolutely amazing! Such an amazing team, exceptional care from everyone.

The staff were great Dr. smicoff was good. The social worker was awful and when baby was taken from me at birth it was an awful experience. I didn't get to say goodbye. It broke me and I tried to go back to the hospital to deal with getting help and they wouldn't help me.

Went to the hospital last week after having an injury at home. Wait times were almost at eight hours. Entire waiting room was full. I was brought in fairly quickly if you call three hours quick because I hit my head. Was taken in quickly …

My 88 year old mother was feeling very ill and we had to do something as she had a fever and was bed ridden for 3 days.
Emergency took her in and she was put in the waiting room for 11 hours without …

Horrific. A Triage Nurse by the name of Jim (refused to give further identifiers) (cisgender white male, mid fifties, brownish hair with some grey, blotchy red skin, droopy eyes, not wearing a mask) dismissed us presenting with clear …

It is enough pain to be very sick and wait for 11 hours to be looked after.
While the nurses are trying all their best to comfort us and help, I went with the receptionist lady asking for help because the vending machine in the waiting …

For the first time, I contacted Energency on an urgent issue. I am very grateful to all the doctors and nurses who were with me. Everyone was very polite, and the staff responded quickly and began to save me. 4 hours after the drip, I felt …
United Nations should degrade the rating of Canada in term of HDI from developed nation to under developing nation untill the situation of health sector remain same as of current.. …

My son had a bellybutton hernia which requires surgery. It took about 1hr. The staff was awesome, I got to suit up & was allowed to go into surgery until he was asleep, then went  to wait for him to get back. Dr.Hyashi called up to let me …

A Disastrous Encounter at the Emergency Room October 31st

I arrived at the emergency room in dire need of immediate assistance, only to …
The best staff anyone could ask for. Checked up on me every 15-20 mins. Made sure I was okay and took me into give me treatment right away.

This is my hospital of choice. Recently I have been very sick and have had to go in twice in 3 months. Once in an ambulance and yesterday being rushed there before my
Partner had to work.  The triage staff is usually a little cold but I really do not fault them as I arrived both times in the night and had to stay overnight in emerge and those poor intake workers were so busy both times, and they are always working. This is not always the case and if you are kind you usually get kindness back.

On my first visit it was a less chaotic night so the wait was less insane and not everyone was rushing around to ensure ease of care. I could not keep anything down and I had a panic attack (which I get fairly often and actively treat) while they were taking my blood because I kept vomiting. One nurse stayed with me and gave me breathing exercises and did them with me while the other nurse RAN to get something to help with both the panic attack but also the thing that caused the panic attack. They talked to me and also listened. The kind and friendly doctor came in after and took the time to listen, process the info and ask good and non-insulting questions.

Last night it was very busy. The triage nurses looked like they had been in a prize fight as I got there a couple hours before changeover to third shift. The nurse that did my intake was a little short with me, but she got me registered and through intake, in like 2 minutes from start to getting both bracelets slapped on you. I was there for about 8 hours last night and the staff, as stretched paper thin as they are, still kept everything very cordial and professional. The medical imaging staff on last night were so kind, and comforting. After I had the imaging done that I needed, i walked back and it was after changeover at the triage station. There was a very kind male staffer who took pity on how overwhelmed, scared, and exhausted I was and let me sleep in an empty quiet room and even sent my carers (nurse, doctor, etc…) in so that I could sleep as much as possible in between (i had been awake for well over 48 hours due to the illness). He even let me stay in that room and sleep until my ride showed up.
The resident doctor they sent in is the human embodiment of where I hope modern medicine continues to head. She was so detailed, she did not make me feel like I was playing it up. We went through everything that was happening and she spoke to me like a peer and not a child. The questions she asked were so helpful and SHE LISTENED TO ALL OF IT AND EVEN VALIDATED WHAT I WAS FEELING. She did everything in her power to help me and that woman is still in her residency!

The only deduction I am giving is because BC hospitals are incredibly short staffed and I think that part of the reason is that these people, who have dedicated their adult lives to helping others, are being asked to build a mansion with duct tape and desperation, with a third of the crew they would need to complete that task under the best of circumstances. VIHA and the BC ministry of health need to take a look and allocate more public funding for these hospital workers and hey, maybe use some of that as tuition money/scholarships for people who can barely afford to stay clothed and fed but would thrive in medical.
The women at the registation desk was very friendly and welcoming. I came in around 11pm and the wait hasn't been too long for the er

My 4 yr old grandson broke his arm badly above the elbow and required surgery.  The entire medical team was fabulous. They gave him a beautiful stuffed monkey and he came out of surgery w/a cast on his arm & a cast on his favourite …

While on vacation in Victoria, At 28 weeks pregnant, I had to be taken by ambulance to the maternity ward where I was well looked after. I was in major pain & the nurses did all they could to comfort me. I was then ushered into emergency surgery that night to remove a cyst off my fallopian tube. Dr. Dennie, was amazing and was able to perform surgery successfully while keeping our unborn baby settled & happy.
They then did all they could to get me back on track and on my flight with my husband and kids the next morning.
I even was given the doctors direct line to keep in contact with her to ensure all continued to go well.
I couldn't have asked for a better experience!!

What a dumb hospital staff is? Me and my wife went for our anatomy scan. We told technician that we don’t want to know the gender of our baby but our friend gonna know it in order to arrange our gender reveal party. When our friend didn’t got call until 3-days and we follow up with midwife clinic here. Her name was Lori. She said the technician never scan gender of our baby. When we excuse her to arrange another scan asap, she is like we don’t guarantee gender scan. U need to change ur party dates. We only want mother and baby healthy bla bla. Seriously? Dozen of our friends got pregnant in last couple years but none of them have this type of experience ever. Ur staff, ur technician is not responsible for their mistake but patient does. Wow so rude staff. That ultrasound technician also very rude. Seems like she had problems with English understanding.

I was admitted through emergency and yes, the wait was long but I was no sicker than most of the people in there.  After blood work and  a ct scan, I was admitted and spent the next week getting sorted out.  The reason I’m writing this is because I received top notch care for my entire stay.  From doctors, nurses, care aids, medical imaging dept, porters, and food services,  the staff were courteous, professional, kind, and caring.  I want to give a special shout out to Mikaila and Elizabeth on 6 north.  During my stay, I had the utmost confidence that my wellness, and that of all patients, was a top priority.  Thank you VGH 💕

Had a big accident on my bike on the way to work. Have nothing but the most amount of respect for those who took great care of me. Thank you for your endless work and compassion for your efforts for myself and all those you help each and every day.

Was admitted to emerge through an ambulance after a car accident with a neck injury. I was waiting for 8 hours in the main lobby with no backrest before being taken in and given a neck brace, I was in a lot of pain and they were shocked that I was not given a neck brace immediately in the event that I become paralyzed from a wrong movement.

I could not lie down and was given no chair while I waited in a storage room for my CT scan, two hours I stood there and the nurse came in and said "You're still here?!" I was given or offered no water or blankets and I was thirsty and cold.

After my CT scan they kept me over-night to see a MRI specialist in the morning, there were no beds available so they put me in a small room with another person in a reclining chair. The reclining chair was broken and I was once again offered no water or blankets, I was unable to sleep and in a lot of pain all night.

There are times when good reviews are challenging to write because of their complexity. In order to write this review of Victoria General Hospital (VGH); I have chosen to write it in sections as it applied to me during my stay.
I arrived at the hospital 15 minutes prior to my admission time. Was directed to the day surgery ward where unfortunately there was incorrect information submitted on my personal health information record from another hospital. Although this mis-information did not lead to my missing my surgery it did cause the admitting staff to take extra precautions. Although I repeatedly told the staff that the information was incorrect; they kept the precautions “in place” until the error was corrected. I was told that patient and staff safety was paramount and seeing how the staff reacted to this mis-information and was totally respectful towards me; that in itself showed me that pre-admission staff are very well trained in their responsibilities and took their work very seriously.
I am especially grateful to both anesthesiologists who spent time with me prior to my surgery.  Both tried to convince me to take a spinal freeze instead of an anesthetic because of breathing issues. However, I was steadfast in wanting to have my surgery done whilst I was under a general anesthetic. Thank you ever so much Doctors for preventing me from “going to the light”.  People say it wasn’t your time; I say it was because of the skill and knowledge of both doctors that I am still alive.
After surgery one enters a PACU-Primary ward that was once called the Recovery ward. In the Victoria General Hospital here is where all the nurse “angels” work. Never in my entire life have I ever seen a more “patient care” dedicated workforce then in this ward. The nurses know their job; do their job without compliant or oversight; engage with each patient as if they are family members and give the care that we all hope to receive.
These nurses do not gather in groups to talk amongst themselves about outside or weekend activities; these nurses are there to do a job and boy do they do it well. My nurse was a petit European lady with blonde hair and she provided me with the comfort and care that is unheard of in today’s hospitals; and from what I observed every other patient was getting similar treatment from their nurse as I was. If only every ward had nurses that had the ambition, the knowledge and the dedication that these nurses have; for if that were the case, most of out medical issues would disappear.
The staffing on floor South 7 were again very responsive to the patients needs and provided better bedside care then I have witnessed in most hospitals. I am again grateful to that staff for assisting me through my recovery.
Overall – this hospital and the departments I engaged with deserve an A for a job well done. However, the PACU Primary staff on the evening of April 24th between the hours of 4 and 8 pm deserves the A+ award. There are none better that these nurses.
This hospital and staff have to be considered as one of the top medical treatment centres on Vancouver Island.

Labour and delivery.

Wonderful staff, I can't remember all your names but two Jasmine RNs, Dr Cooper, RN Kathleen, but thank you. You made our delivery and post labour experience excellent for us and Goldie. Thanks for what you do, it's really special!

My wife had a medical issue. We had a stay of 19 hours in the hospital emergency area. In that time she had a blood test, Ultrasound, a doctor visit, and the needed medication in the one visit. It was time well spent in the hospital. We were relived it was not series. (It was far better then wasting time at a medical clinic for a 5 minute visit with a doctor, that yield no results). Thank you Victoria General Hospital.
Very long wait in the ER compared to Germany but Dr Stefani was incredibly kind and competent, as was the rest of the staff

Twelve days ago, I thought something was wrong with my eye so  I had a friend drive me to VGH. Dr Jones treated me and set me up an appointment with an eye specialist. The specialist sent me for a 4:00 appointment with a retina specialist and the next day I had lazar surgery. Had it not been for the referral to the eye specialist, my retina would have probably detached and I could have lost some sight in the eye. There is an incredible  amount of professionalism at VGH and I can't thank you enough.

This a new review from three months ago. I had spinal stenosis surgery on February 7th, 2022. The nursing and other staff went beyond in post op care. First, I was fortunate enough to have a private room.

The ward was overcrowded and the nurses were overworked but they and the Care aids were amazing. They washed me and got me up walking the first day. They were very kind and efficient. I felt well cared for. All the nurses were encouraging. They had their masks on the entire time I was there. I loved their dry sense of humour as well.

Dr. Hentschel did a great job of the surgery but I have a separate review on his website.

The anaesthetist was very kind and caring and so were the nurses before and in the OR.

OT and Physio secured a walker for me the next day and arranged for all my equipment to be picked up upon my release and an appointment with aftercare.

I had a very good experience all around and felt well taken care of. Thank you.

I had a gallstone/gall bladder surgery in November 2023. I was supposed to stay overnight. No one could inform me as to whether the gall bladder had been removed with my gallstones. My physician had left it in my file. No one knew if I was supposed to leave the next morning. A doctor finally signed the release form.

I did not need much care. The other three patients, all gall bladder patients, needed more care. The nurse apologized that she had not got to me. I felt sorry for the nurse as she was definitely run off her feet. Later, my surgeon told me that the hospital is supposed to have 7 nurses on duty but they are down to 3 the last couple years on most wards.

I have never experienced such a horrible pharmacy. I have a number of medications. I sent the complete list with dosage times etc. I did not receive my meds on time. They forgot several of my meds and the proper times and amount of dosage. When the nurse came with them , I pointed out the incorrectness. I told her that I carry my meds and just to get rid of the incorrect ones they sent. The nurse told me this was not a new experience. The pharmacy made mistakes like this all the time. Note: that did not happen when I was in for spinal stenosis surgery 18 months ago.

My sister worked at the hospital as a pharmacist until a couple years ago. Pharmacists earn between $11000. to $125000. a year. It must be nice to have a job where you can earn that and not have to do your job correctly.

Note:
Please take your medications with you if you are staying overnight as this inefficient department will not not give you the proper medications and dosage times.

I wrote out a giant message, a warning really, telling of just the horrible things this hospital has done to my family alone; but what's the point! I save my words and just tell you, if you care about your loved ones, do not send them here. if you care about yourself, avoid at all costs!
17, you can do better come. This hospital I would never recommend. Unless you like being locked up and tied up. They are ungodly.

The doctor l saw was wonderful and despite being very busy took the time to listen.  The nurses were kind although at times very curt in their response.  The problem in this hospital ER is the triage  system.  I sat for approximately  6 hours in the waiting room so l saw a lot of patients come and go.  And l realize that people in the waiting room have no idea of the status of people being brought in by ambulance who may need immediate  attention.  However when you have been sitting for hours and you see someone come in with a cough and they only have to wait about an hour, are seen and were given a rx.  There is something wrong.  People were getting angry and upset, security had to be called several times.  People were left sitting to watch other people who arrived after them receiving treatment and leaving.  Lots of people waited for hours and then gave up and left.  I was at the emergency  department for a total of 12 hours, l saw the doctor, received something  for pain and had an ultra sound.  When it was suggested that l have a cat scan which would mean more hours waiting l told the doctor l was exhausted, hadn't any sleep and all l wanted to do was go home.  I can't imagine what it's like to work in emergency,  l can't imagine how many sick people give up, go home and only end up sicker.  I blame the government for this situation, they underpaid family doctors until they gave up their practices.  Now their patients flow like a river into emergency departments.  The system isn't broken, there isn't any kind of system at all.

Came in for dental surgery on my 5 yr old. Was told 1 parent could be in room during operation. Was told they would give sedative medication prior to mask to be put to sleep. At OR was told parent could not be in room with child. Tried to explain this and security was called. They did not give sedative prior to mask and forcefully applied gas until she was knocked out. Very traumatizing experience mostly for my 5 yr old but the whole family in general. Lied about procedures twice. Child now traumatized of medical procedures.

I could hear the nurses complaining and mocking me when I went to emerg for possible e coli poisoning. Felt as though I were dying while they made fun of me and heard a nurse say she wanted to kick me out. All I ever asked for was gravol for nausea and they treated me like I was just looking for drugs. I was in pain and hadn't ate, drank or slept in days. I would rather die at home and I think the ER staff would happily agree to me doing that. HORRIBLE people work there.

Whatever you do, don’t even bother trying to time out the length of your visit by the clock on the wall. If your problem isn’t life threatening  most likely they’ll run out of space and not have any doctors that can see you anyways.
I’ve never had a problem with VGH when my appointments are scheduled but their ER needs help, and they have patients who need their help that they’re not taking care of. I have no access to my results, and found out the reason I’m not able to see a doctor is because they’re waiting for more to come in.
It’s extremely frustrating when you’re in pain and forced to sit on a shopping cart turned into wheelchair with only a blanket for comfort to sit on and a push bar that stabs your bad if you even think of leaning backward. No medication to control pain because it’s not allowed in the waiting room, and nurses who don’t even look at you when they walk by.
I haven’t been able to sleep because of this stupid wheelchair, I’m in pain because I don’t know if my ankle is fractured or dislocated, and frankly I just want to pack myself up and and chalk up the past 8 hours as a joke and go home.

At least with an urgent care clinic you get to see the doctor. if you’re not bleeding out, cut your losses and go to an urgent care clinic. At least it feels like they’re trying to help you there.

I have a friend in the hospital.
She finally told  me that she is MRSA positive.
I have surgery in 4 weeks and can not have any infections beforehand. …

I went into this hospital because it was the closest.I am from out of province but staying in Sooke for awhile. I sat there for 12 hours went in on a Tuesday left on a Wednesday. Had a test done ,its exactly two weeks to the day I cannot …

Over the years their care has never changed. They discriminate against women and target vulnerable people. They sent me away with a severe infection white blood cell count through the roof saying it was a stomach bug. Doctor let me sit and lose 5 pints of blood in emergency room begging for help for 2 hours straight.

I have unfortunately had to go the the E.R many times in my life due to health issues, but I am always so impressed by the Nurses, Doctors and staff, and their kindness and support and thoroughness. I think we all need to be a little kinder and more patient with our Healthcare workers and be thankful for them as it's not an easy job.

No nurses wear masks. One of them coughed on my partner as she was getting checked out for her ultrasound and she has a compromised immune system. Wait time is minimum 6 hours, severely under resourced. This hospital DOES NOT CARE for its patients. Worst run hospital I've ever been in.

WARNING!!!  Staff refuse to follow doctor's orders  about how to care for patients with specific health and safety needs!!! Because of this negligence, many injuries (and even some loss of lives) happen yet the hospital refuses to treat any injuries caused by staff.

I had the staff disobey doctor's order's when I was a patient there following an accident..... and almost immediately they heard me screaming I pain after I fell badly.  So they had to pick up my body off the ground and listen to me cry out in pain and frustration when they refused to listen to me about the fact that my shoulder was broken! I'm a nurse - yet they refused to believe that their negligence could be at fault. it took 3 weeks before they agreed to the x-ray and yes, it was broken but unfortunately by then, since there had been no treatment for so long, it had become a 'frozen shoulder'. So I had to endure 20 months of 3-5 times a week in physiotherapy before I had physical control of my arm again!!!

This hospital is full of unskilled, unintelligent staff that care more about their smoke breaks than following vital orders from doctors about patient care! Go to ANY OTHER HOSPITAL if you want adequate care.

Not impressed with this hospital at all.
